question: What role do mediators play in negotiations when parties in dispute cannot agree, and what steps do they take to facilitate discussion?
reasoning: Requires combining 8.44.4 (mediator role) and 8.45.2 (mediation process)
answer_texts: The appointed Mediator’s role shall be to assist the parties in dispute in their negotiations, with the aspiration of settling the dispute submitted for Mediation by reaching a mutual agreement. In this regard, the appointed Mediator may assist such parties by: (1) identifying the issues; and (2) facilitate discussion of the issues.

Each appointed Mediator shall be impartial and independent of the parties in dispute during the Mediation and shall disclose any facts or circumstances which may reasonably conflict with their independence. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the parties in dispute may mutually agree in writing to authorise any appointed Mediator to continue their appointment after acknowledging the Mediator’s aforementioned disclosure.

Following the commence of the Mediation, the Mediator shall: (1) hold an initial conference or otherwise communicate with the parties in dispute (collectively or separately) to discuss the manner in which the Mediation will proceed, including the timeline and key events in the Mediation; (2) call for and facilitate the exchange of information between the parties in dispute relevant for the Mediation, which may include a summary of their views and copies of material documents on which they rely; (3) arrange Mediation sessions where the parties in dispute may present their views and negotiate to attempt to settle the dispute, as facilitated by the Mediator; and (4) take such other steps as mutually agreed or otherwise deemed appropriate by the Mediator under Article 8.45.

question: How do mediators balance their impartiality and independence with the possibility of parties in dispute continuing to work with them after disclosure of potential conflicts?
reasoning: Requires combining 8.44.6 (mediator impartiality and independence) and 8.44.6 (mutual agreement to continue appointment)
answer_texts: The appointed Mediator’s role shall be to assist the parties in dispute in their negotiations, with the aspiration of settling the dispute submitted for Mediation by reaching a mutual agreement. In this regard, the appointed Mediator may assist such parties by: (1) identifying the issues; and (2) facilitate discussion of the issues.

Each appointed Mediator shall be impartial and independent of the parties in dispute during the Mediation and shall disclose any facts or circumstances which may reasonably conflict with their independence. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the parties in dispute may mutually agree in writing to authorise any appointed Mediator to continue their appointment after acknowledging the Mediator’s aforementioned disclosure.

Following the commence of the Mediation, the Mediator shall: (1) hold an initial conference or otherwise communicate with the parties in dispute (collectively or separately) to discuss the manner in which the Mediation will proceed, including the timeline and key events in the Mediation; (2) call for and facilitate the exchange of information between the parties in dispute relevant for the Mediation, which may include a summary of their views and copies of material documents on which they rely; (3) arrange Mediation sessions where the parties in dispute may present their views and negotiate to attempt to settle the dispute, as facilitated by the Mediator; and (4) take such other steps as mutually agreed or otherwise deemed appropriate by the Mediator under Article 8.45.

question: Under what circumstances might a Settlement Agreement made through mediation be refused by the ITTF Tribunal?
reasoning: Requires combining 8.51.1 (recording Settlement Agreement) and 8.51.2 (conditions for refusing to record Settlement Agreement)
answer_texts: Where a Settlement Agreement has been made through a Mediation, any party to that Settlement Agreement or the Mediator conducting the Mediation may apply to the ITTF Tribunal court to record that Settlement Agreement as a decision of the ITTF Tribunal within 21 days of the date of that Settlement Agreement.

The ITTF Tribunal may refuse to record a Settlement Agreement as a decision of the ITTF Tribunal if: (1) that Settlement Agreement is void or voidable due to incapacity, fraud, misrepresentation, duress, coercion, illegality, or any other ground for invalidating a contract; (2) the subject matter of that Settlement Agreement is not capable of settlement; (3) any term of that Settlement Agreement is not capable of enforcement as a decision of the ITTF Tribunal; (4) that Settlement Agreement is not final or binding according to its terms; (5) the terms of that Settlement Agreement are too incomprehensible to be capable of enforcement; (6) there was any serious breach of the standards applicable to the Mediator or the Mediation without which breach any party in that dispute would not have entered into that Settlement Agreement, such as a failure by the Mediator to disclose circumstances that raise justifiable doubts as to their impartiality or independence which had a material impact or undue influence on any such party; or (7) the recording of that Settlement Agreement as a decision of the ITTF Tribunal is contrary to public policy.

question: What are the key factors that the ITTF Tribunal will consider when evaluating a request to record a Settlement Agreement as a decision?
reasoning: Requires combining 8.51.2 (conditions for refusing to record Settlement Agreement) and analyzing the list of grounds for refusal
answer_texts: Where a Settlement Agreement has been made through a Mediation, any party to that Settlement Agreement or the Mediator conducting the Mediation may apply to the ITTF Tribunal court to record that Settlement Agreement as a decision of the ITTF Tribunal within 21 days of the date of that Settlement Agreement.

The ITTF Tribunal may refuse to record a Settlement Agreement as a decision of the ITTF Tribunal if: (1) that Settlement Agreement is void or voidable due to incapacity, fraud, misrepresentation, duress, coercion, illegality, or any other ground for invalidating a contract; (2) the subject matter of that Settlement Agreement is not capable of settlement; (3) any term of that Settlement Agreement is not capable of enforcement as a decision of the ITTF Tribunal; (4) that Settlement Agreement is not final or binding according to its terms; (5) the terms of that Settlement Agreement are too incomprehensible to be capable of enforcement; (6) there was any serious breach of the standards applicable to the Mediator or the Mediation without which breach any party in that dispute would not have entered into that Settlement Agreement, such as a failure by the Mediator to disclose circumstances that raise justifiable doubts as to their impartiality or independence which had a material impact or undue influence on any such party; or (7) the recording of that Settlement Agreement as a decision of the ITTF Tribunal is contrary to public policy.

question: What happens if the ITTF Head of Integrity position is vacant, and what are the responsibilities of the ITTF Integrity Board Chair in such a situation?
reasoning: Requires synthesizing information from [9.5.2] (composition of the ITTF Integrity Board) and [9.7.5] (temporary assumption of the ITTF Head of Integrity office)
answer_texts: The ITTF Integrity Board shall comprise of: (1) A maximum of five Independent Members, one of them being the ITTF Integrity Board Chair; (2) one ITTF Executive Board member (as determined by the ITTF Executive Board) to be a non-voting member of the ITTF Integrity Board; and (3) the ITTF Head of Integrity ex officio who will also be a non-voting member of  the ITTF Integrity Board. If at any point, the position of ITTF Head of Integrity  is vacant, their position on the ITTF Integrity Board will also be vacant.

No ITTF Integrity Board Chair or Independent Member themselves and their immediate family members may, during their term of office as ITTF Integrity Board member and for four years prior to their initial appointment to office (collectively, the “Independence Requirements”): (1) hold any official function in ITTF, a member association of ITTF or an associated organisation of ITTF; and (2) have any material business relationship with ITTF, a member association of  ITTF or an associated organisation of ITTF,

The Independent Members of the ITTF Integrity Board are required at all times to: (1) act at all times in good faith and in the best interest of the ITTF Integrity Unit; (2) exercise the powers of the ITTF Integrity Board for proper purposes; (3) act and ensure that the ITTF Integrity Board acts in accordance with the ITTF Statutes, the Applicable Rules and these Regulations; (4) make reasonable efforts to attend and actively participate in all ITTF Integrity  Board meetings; (5) maintain a reputation for high standards of business conduct; (6) exercise the care, diligence and skill that any reasonable ITTF Integrity Board member would exercise in the same circumstances; 9: Integrity Regulations ITTF Statutes 2025   Page 224 (7) comply and do not publicly disagree with the ITTF Integrity Board’s decisions, even if the Independent Member privately does not agree with them; (8) act and operate independently from the other organs of the ITTF, unless specified in these Regulations; (9) not agree to the ITTF Integrity Unit incurring any obligations unless they reasonably believe at that time that the ITTF Integrity Unit will be able to perform the obligations when it is required to do so; (10) except for the ITTF Integrity Board Chair, not speak or make statements publicly on behalf of the ITTF Integrity Board unless authorised to do so by the ITTF Integrity Board Chair or in accordance with delegated authority in writing from the ITTF Integrity Board; (11) disclose to the ITTF Integrity Board the nature and extent of any interest they may have in a transaction or proposed transaction of the ITTF Integrity Board as soon as they become aware of such interest or such transaction; and (12) participate in the annual review of the ITTF Integrity Board’s performance in  the manner decided by the ITTF Integrity Board.

If the ITTF Head of Integrity office is vacant, the ITTF Integrity Board shall appoint  an ITTF Integrity Officer or an ITTF Integrity Board Member to temporarily assume that office until a new ITTF Head of Integrity is appointed. (1) No provision of these Regulations or the ITTF Statutes shall be prejudiced by the vacancy of the ITTF Head of Integrity office.

If an integrity matter arises between the ITTF Integrity Board meetings, the ITTF Head of Integrity will inform the ITTF Integrity Board Chair and the latter will determine its urgency and the need to call for an extraordinary meeting of the ITTF Integrity Board, or whether it can be decided during the next scheduled meeting.

question: How does the ITTF Integrity Board Chair determine the urgency of an integrity matter, and what are the possible outcomes?
reasoning: Requires combining information from [9.6.1] (Independence Requirements) and [9.8.4] (informing the ITTF Integrity Board Chair of integrity matters)

If at any point, the position of ITTF Head of Integrity  is vacant, their position on the ITTF Integrity Board will also be vacant.

No ITTF Integrity Board Chair or Independent Member themselves and their immediate family members may, during their term of office as ITTF Integrity Board member and for four years prior to their initial appointment to office (collectively, the “Independence Requirements”): (1) hold any official function in ITTF, a member association of ITTF or an associated organisation of ITTF; and (2) have any material business relationship with ITTF, a member association of  ITTF or an associated organisation of ITTF,

The Independent Members of the ITTF Integrity Board are required at all times to: (1) act at all times in good faith and in the best interest of the ITTF Integrity Unit; (2) exercise the powers of the ITTF Integrity Board for proper purposes; (3) act and ensure that the ITTF Integrity Board acts in accordance with the ITTF Statutes, the Applicable Rules and these Regulations; (4) make reasonable efforts to attend and actively participate in all ITTF Integrity  Board meetings; (5) maintain a reputation for high standards of business conduct; (6) exercise the care, diligence and skill that any reasonable ITTF Integrity Board member would exercise in the same circumstances; 9: Integrity Regulations ITTF Statutes 2025   Page 224 (7) comply and do not publicly disagree with the ITTF Integrity Board’s decisions, even if the Independent Member privately does not agree with them; (8) act and operate independently from the other organs of the ITTF, unless specified in these Regulations; (9) not agree to the ITTF Integrity Unit incurring any obligations unless they reasonably believe at that time that the ITTF Integrity Unit will be able to perform the obligations when it is required to do so; (10) except for the ITTF Integrity Board Chair, not speak or make statements publicly on behalf of the ITTF Integrity Board unless authorised to do so by the ITTF Integrity Board Chair or in accordance with delegated authority in writing from the ITTF Integrity Board; (11) disclose to the ITTF Integrity Board the nature and extent of any interest they may have in a transaction or proposed transaction of the ITTF Integrity Board as soon as they become aware of such interest or such transaction; and (12) participate in the annual review of the ITTF Integrity Board’s performance in  the manner decided by the ITTF Integrity Board.

If the ITTF Head of Integrity office is vacant, the ITTF Integrity Board shall appoint  an ITTF Integrity Officer or an ITTF Integrity Board Member to temporarily assume that office until a new ITTF Head of Integrity is appointed. (1) No provision of these Regulations or the ITTF Statutes shall be prejudiced by the vacancy of the ITTF Head of Integrity office.

If an integrity matter arises between the ITTF Integrity Board meetings, the ITTF Head of Integrity will inform the ITTF Integrity Board Chair and the latter will determine its urgency and the need to call for an extraordinary meeting of the ITTF Integrity Board, or whether it can be decided during the next scheduled meeting.

question: What happens if an athlete or a table tennis party is suspected of obstructing or delaying an investigation?
reasoning: Requires synthesizing information from 9.17.10 (obstruction of investigation) and 9.17.9 (immediate compliance with investigation notice)
answer_texts: In addition to receiving Reports in accordance to R 9.15.1 above, the ITTF Integrity Unit may put in place mechanisms to gather intelligence that may 9: Integrity Regulations ITTF Statutes 2025 Page 229 assist in assessing the compliance (or otherwise) of Table Tennis Parties with the Applicable Rules from all available sources, including law enforcement, other regulatory and disciplinary bodies, investigative journalists, members of the public, and third parties. In particular, the ITTF Integrity Unit may facilitate anonymous reporting by third parties where it considers appropriate and possible to do so.

The ITTF Integrity Unit may share intelligence that it holds about any Table Tennis Party with other appropriate authorities, including law enforcement and other regulatory and disciplinary bodies, where the ITTF Integrity Unit consider that such sharing is necessary in order to: (1) Effectively carry out an investigation or prosecution under these Regulations or to administer or enforce any matter falling under these Regulations; (2) Protect the integrity of the ITTF, the Table Tennis Parties, or the sport of Table Tennis, generally; (3) Prevent or detect crime or other offences or preserve the health or well- being of any person; or (4) Fulfil any legal obligation of the ITTF or the ITTF Integrity Unit, including the obligation to demonstrate the ITTF Integrity Unit’s compliance with the ITTF Statutes.

As part of an Investigation Notice, the ITTF Head of Integrity may require the Alleged Person or Table Tennis Party to: (1) Attend before the ITTF Integrity Unit for an interview, or to answer any question, or to provide a written statement setting out their knowledge of any relevant facts and circumstances. (1) Any interview will take place at a time and place determined by the ITTF Head of Integrity, and the Alleged Person or Table Tennis Party will be given reasonable notice in writing of the requirement to attend. (2) Interviews may be recorded and/or transcribed; (3) The Alleged Person or Table Tennis Party will be entitled to have legal counsel and an interpreter present. For the Alleged Person this shall be at their own expense (subject to an application for financial assistance from the ITTF). For a Table Tennis Party, they shall bear the cost of legal counsel (subject to an application for financial assistance from the ITTF), whilst the ITTF shall provide an interpreter; (2) Provide (or procure to the best of their ability, the provision by a third party) for inspection, copying and/or downloading any records or files (whether existing in hard copy or electronic format) that the ITTF Head of Integrity reasonably believes may contain relevant information (such as itemised 9: Integrity Regulations ITTF Statutes 2025   Page 232 telephone billing statements, bank statements, ledgers, cryptocurrency wallets, transaction histories for any money transfer service or e-wallet, Internet service records, notes, files, correspondence, emails, and text of SMS, Whatsapp, Telegram, WeChat or similar messages received and sent); (3) Provide (or procure to the best of their ability, the provision by a third party) for inspection, copying and/or downloading any electronic storage device that the ITTF Head of Integrity reasonably believes may contain relevant information (such as cloud-based servers, computers, hard drives, tapes, disks, mobile telephones, laptop computers, tablets, and other mobile storage devices); (4) Provide full and unlimited access to their premises for the purpose of securing information, records, articles or things that are the subject of an Investigation Notice; (5) Provide full and unlimited access to any social media accounts and data accessed via cloud services; and/or (6) Provide passwords, login credentials and other identifying information required to access information that is the subject of an Investigation Notice.

Where an Investigation Notice relates to any information, record, article or thing that the ITTF Head of Integrity reasonably believes is capable of being damaged, altered, destroyed or hidden (any electronic storage device or electronically stored information will be deemed to meet this criterion), then for the purposes of evidence preservation, the ITTF Head of Integrity may require the Alleged Person or Table Tennis Party to comply with the Investigation Notice immediately upon receipt of it. In such a case: (1) The Alleged Person or Table Tennis Party must immediately comply with the Investigation Notice in full, including permitting the ITTF Head of Integrity to take immediate possession of, copy and/or download the information, record, article or thing; (2) A refusal or failure by the Alleged Person or Table Tennis Party to comply immediately with the Investigation Notice may constitute an independent violation of these Regulations and the ITTF Code of Ethics; and (3) Any attempted or actual damage, alteration, destruction or hiding of such information, record, article or thing upon receipt of or after the Investigation Notice will constitute an independent violation of these Regulations and the ITTF Code of Ethics.

If the Alleged Person or Table Tennis Party obstructs or delays an investigation in any manner, whether or not in relation to an Investigation Notice (for example; by providing false, misleading or incomplete 9: Integrity Regulations ITTF Statutes 2025 Page 233 information or documentation or by tampering or destroying any documentation or other information that may be relevant to the investigation), it may also constitute a violation of these Regulations and the ITTF Code of Ethics.

question: What steps does the ITTF Head of Integrity take when they decide to initiate an investigation?
reasoning: Requires combining 9.16.6 (considering information to establish a Prima Facie Case) and 9.17.3 (conducted investigations fairly and impartially)
answer_texts: If, upon review, the ITTF Head of Integrity considers the Report to be frivolous, vexatious, malicious, or otherwise an abuse of process, they may decide to take no further action. The ITTF Head of Integrity may take action against a malicious, frivolous, vexatious Report, if they consider that the filing is in of itself a violation of the ITTF Statutes.

In addition to information provided in a Report, the ITTF Head of Integrity may consider information that has come to their attention by whatever means to establish whether there is a Prima Facie Case, and in such circumstances, they shall initiate an investigation against the Alleged Person in accordance with these Regulations.

The ITTF Head of Integrity will conduct each investigation fairly, objectively and impartially. (1) The ITTF Head of Integrity will be open to and consider all possible outcomes at each key stage of the investigation, and will seek to gather not only available evidence of a violation but also any available evidence indicating that there is no case to answer. 9: Integrity Regulations ITTF Statutes 2025 Page 231 (2) The ITTF Head of Integrity shall fully document their conduct of investigations, the evaluation of information and evidence identified in the course of investigations, and the outcome of investigations.

The ITTF Head of Integrity will notify the Alleged Person of the investigation and of the possible violation(s) to which the investigation relates, and will give the Alleged Person an opportunity to make a written submission as part of the investigation. The ITTF Head of Integrity shall decide when this notification should be made.

If the ITTF Head of Integrity determines that the Alleged Person has a case to answer for violation of the Applicable Rules, the ITTF Integrity Unit shall: (1) charge the Alleged Person with violation of the Applicable Rules; (2) present that charge before the ITTF Tribunal for hearing and determination; and (3) pursue and defend (as applicable) any application and/or appeal arising in relation to such proceedings.

question: What happens if the ITTF Head of Integrity determines that the Alleged Person has a case to answer for violation of the Applicable Rules?
reasoning: Requires combining 9.18.2 (if a case to answer for violation of the Applicable Rules) and 9.17.4 (notification of the investigation)
answer_texts: If, upon review, the ITTF Head of Integrity considers the Report to be frivolous, vexatious, malicious, or otherwise an abuse of process, they may decide to take no further action. question: What are the circumstances under which the ITTF Head of Integrity may decide not to commence an investigation?
reasoning: Requires combining 9.16.5 (Prima Facie Case) and 9.16.7 (suspension or termination of investigation)
answer_texts: If the evidence submitted with, or subsequent to, any Report is considered by the ITTF Head of Integrity to establish a Prima Facie Case, the ITTF Head of Integrity will cause an investigation to be commenced, unless in their view and in consultation with the Integrity Unit Board, there is a good reason not to cause an investigation to be commenced either immediately or at all.

If the ITTF Head of Integrity determines that no Prima Facie Case is established, the ITTF Head of Integrity may at their discretion suspend or terminate case. (1) Grounds do not need to be given for the commencement or, suspension of an investigation for any alleged breach of any Applicable Rule. Such a decision shall not be subject to appeal. (2) In the case of a termination of an investigation, ground will be provided, it shall be treated as a final decision and therefore may be appealed in accordance with the ITTF Regulations.

Where the ITTF Head of Integrity suspects that an Alleged Person may have committed a violation of the Applicable Rules and/or a Table Tennis Party may have information about a potential violation of the Applicable Rules by an Alleged Person, it may make a written demand (an “Investigation Notice”) for information relating to the potential violation. (1) The ITTF Head of Integrity may issue such Investigation Notice at any time after a Report has been filed, including during its initial investigation or at any point after a Notice of Charge has been issued. (2) If necessary, the ITTF Head of Integrity may issue more than one Investigation Notice in the same investigation.

question: When might the ITTF Head of Integrity issue a written demand for information relating to a potential violation of the Applicable Rules?
reasoning: Requires combining 9.16.5 (Prima Facie Case) and 9.17.6 (Investigation Notice)
answer_texts: If the evidence submitted with, or subsequent to, any Report is considered by the ITTF Head of Integrity to establish a Prima Facie Case, the ITTF Head of Integrity will cause an investigation to be commenced, unless in their view and in consultation with the Integrity Unit Board, there is a good reason not to cause an investigation to be commenced either immediately or at all.

question: If a table tennis player is sent a Notice of Charge, what are their options for responding to the charges, and what happens if they fail to respond in time?
reasoning: Requires synthesizing information from 9.19.1 (Notice of Charge) and 9.22.1 (consequences of failing to respond)
answer_texts: The ITTF Integrity Unit will discharge its rights and responsibilities in good faith in all cases, taking into account both at the point of determining whether to issue a Notice of Charge and throughout any proceedings that follow: (1) The likelihood of a charge being upheld (including considering the strength of any evidence relied upon, the merits of the ITTF Integrity Unit’s case, and how the defence case is likely to affect the ITTF Integrity Unit’s case); and (2) Whether bringing or continuing to pursue the charge is necessary and proportionate to the objectives of the imperatives underlying these Regulations. 9: Integrity Regulations ITTF Statutes 2025   Page 234

If the ITTF Head of Integrity determines that the Alleged Person has a case to answer for violation of the Applicable Rules, the ITTF Integrity Unit will prepare and send a written notice of charge to the Alleged Person (“Notice of Charge”), which will contain the following information: (1) The specific provision(s) of the Applicable Rules that the Alleged Person is alleged to have violated; (2) The facts alleged in support of such charge(s); (3) where applicable, the details of any provisional suspension imposed on the Alleged Person pursuant to R9.20 pending determination of the charge(s); and (4) the sanction(s) that the ITTF Integrity Unit says should be imposed under the Applicable Rules if the charge(s) is/are upheld; (5) the Alleged Person’s right: (1) to admit the charge(s) and to accept the sanction(s) specified in the Notice of Charge; (2) to admit the charge(s) but to dispute (or seek to mitigate) the sanction(s) specified in the Notice of Charge, and to have the matter of sanction(s) determined by the ITTF Tribunal in accordance with R 9.28 if it cannot be agreed between the parties; or (3) to dispute the charge(s) and to have the charge(s) determined (along with any sanctions, where a charge is upheld) by the ITTF Tribunal in accordance with the requirements of R9.23; and (6) the deadline for the Alleged Person to provide a response to the charges (which shall be no fewer than 14 days from the date of receipt of the Notice of Charge by the Alleged Person).

Where the Alleged Person: (1) Admits the charge(s) and accepts the sanction(s) specified in the Notice of Charge (or accepts other sanction(s) proposed by the ITTF Integrity Unit); or (2) Fails to respond by the deadline specified in the Notice of Charge (which will be deemed to amount to (a) a waiver of the Alleged Person’s right to have the charge(s) and/or sanction(s) determined by the ITTF Tribunal; (b) an admission of the charge(s); and (c) an acceptance of the sanction(s) specified in the Notice of Charge), the ITTF Integrity Unit will issue a public notice confirming the violation(s) committed and the sanction(s) imposed, and that notice will take effect as if it were a final decision of the ITTF Tribunal made in accordance with R9.29. Alternatively, where they sees fit (such as where the ITTF Integrity Unit has specified a range of potential sanction(s) in the Notice of Charge), the ITTF Head of Integrity may refer the matter to the ITTF Tribunal to determine the sanction(s) to be imposed in accordance with R9.28.

Where the ITTF Integrity Unit considers it appropriate to do so (for example; to minimise the burden on resources, or to achieve an expeditious and proportionate outcome to a case), the ITTF Head of Integrity may agree terms with an Alleged Person who has been charged with a violation of the Applicable Rules for disposition of the charge without a hearing. 9: Integrity Regulations ITTF Statutes 2025 Page 237 (1) Such disposition will include confirmation of the commission of the violation(s) charged and acceptance of the sanction(s) to be imposed under these Regulations. (2) Any such discussion between the ITTF Head of Integrity and the Alleged Person in relation to the possibility of an agreed sanction will take place on a “without prejudice” basis and in such a manner that they will not delay or in any other way interfere with the proceedings.

question: Under what circumstances may the ITTF Head of Integrity refer a matter to the ITTF Tribunal to determine the sanction to be imposed, and what is the process for this referral?
reasoning: Requires combining information from 9.19.1 (Notice of Charge) and 9.22.2 (disposition of charges without a hearing)

question: What are the grounds on which the ITTF Head of Integrity may apply for a provisional suspension of an Alleged Person, and what rights does the Alleged Person have in response?
reasoning: Requires synthesizing information from 9.20.1 (grounds for provisional suspension) and 9.20.5 (rights of the Alleged Person)
answer_texts: In any case where the ITTF Integrity Unit issues a Notice of Charge to the Alleged Person, the ITTF Head of Integrity may submit an application to the ITTF Integrity Board for a provisional suspension of the Alleged Person pending determination of the charge(s) after considering one or more of the following factors: (1) the likelihood that the integrity of the sport of Table Tennis will be undermined; 9: Integrity Regulations ITTF Statutes 2025 Page 235 (2) the seriousness of the alleged violation(s); (3) the necessity or desirability of the provisional suspension in facilitating the conduct of any investigation or proceeding by ITTF Integrity Unit or any other relevant body; and (4) the potential prejudice to the Alleged Person in imposing provisional suspension.

The application by the ITTF Head of Integrity to the ITTF Integrity Board for a provisional suspension of the Alleged Person can may be submitted when the Notice of Charge is issued or at any time thereafter. The ITTF Head of Integrity may apply for a provisional eligibility suspension to be issued prior to this time where there is compelling evidence that the Alleged Person is a current and ongoing risk to a Table Tennis Party and/or the integrity of the sport of Table Tennis.

An Alleged Person whose eligibility is provisionally suspended has the right to apply to the ITTF Tribunal for an order lifting or limiting the provisional eligibility suspension. The provisional eligibility suspension may be lifted or limited if the Alleged Person demonstrates to the satisfaction of the ITTF Tribunal that: (1) the facts alleged in support of the charge(s) do not give rise to a Prima Facie Case; (2) the case against the Alleged Person has no reasonable prospect of success; (3) there is no real risk that the integrity of the sport of Table Tennis would be undermined; or (4) other facts exist that make it clearly unfair, in all circumstances of the case, to make the Alleged Person serve a provisional suspension prior to the determination of the charge(s) against the Alleged Person. This ground is to be construed strictly, and applied only in truly exceptional circumstances. (1) The fact that the provisional eligibility suspension would prevent the Alleged Person from participating in a particular Table Tennis competition or event or to stand or election or appointment will not qualify as exceptional circumstances for these purposes. 9: Integrity Regulations ITTF Statutes 2025   Page 236

An Alleged Person whose eligibility is not provisionally suspended by the ITTF Integrity Unit may, at any time, notify the ITTF Integrity Unit that the Alleged Person will accept a voluntary provisional suspension pending determination of the charge(s). Such voluntary provisional eligibility suspension will come into effect only upon receipt by the ITTF Integrity Unit of written confirmation of the Alleged Person’s acceptance of the provisional eligibility suspension. No adverse inference will be drawn from such acceptance.

Except in exceptional circumstances where the ITTF Integrity Unit reasonably deems it necessary for the purposes of protecting the integrity of Table Tennis and/or any of Table Tennis Party (for example in circumstances where there is significant damaging and/or incorrect media speculation), the ITTF Integrity Unit shall not publicly identify any Alleged Person until they have been formally charged, at which point the ITTF Integrity Unit shall be entitled to publicly announce the name of the Alleged Person charged and the offences with which they have been charged. Thereafter, the ITTF Integrity Unit shall not comment publicly on the specific facts of a pending case, except in response to public comments made by (or on behalf of) the Alleged Person or their representatives or where otherwise necessary to preserve the public’s confidence in the ability of the ITTF Integrity Unit to fight corruption in Table Tennis.

question: What happens if a Table Tennis Party is under investigation and the ITTF Integrity Unit is not satisfied with the investigation process?
reasoning: Requires combining 9.25.1 (ITTF Integrity Unit direction to transfer investigation) and 9.21.1 (ITTF Integrity Unit order to exclude a person)
answer_texts: Where the ITTF Integrity Unit has sufficient evidence and is satisfied that any person (including a person who is not a Table Tennis Party) has likely breached an Applicable Rule and may undermine the integrity of the sport of Table Tennis, the ITTF Integrity Unit may issue an order directing that person to be excluded from any Table Tennis Party’s competition, event, or activity and the Table Tennis Parties shall comply with such order.

In the event that any ITTF Member Association or, affiliated organisation, undertakes any investigation or proceeding against a Table Tennis Party and the ITTF Integrity Unit reasonably deems that such investigation and/or proceeding is not conducted in a satisfactory manner, the ITTF Integrity Unit may direct for such investigation or proceeding to be transferred to the ITTF Integrity Unit.

question: What are the consequences for a person who has likely breached an Applicable Rule and may undermine the integrity of the sport, and if they are part of a Table Tennis Party?
reasoning: Requires combining 9.21.1 (ITTF Integrity Unit order to exclude a person) and 9.21.1 (compliance with the order by Table Tennis Parties)
answer_texts: Where the ITTF Integrity Unit has sufficient evidence and is satisfied that any person (including a person who is not a Table Tennis Party) has likely breached an Applicable Rule and may undermine the integrity of the sport of Table Tennis, the ITTF Integrity Unit may issue an order directing that person to be excluded from any Table Tennis Party’s competition, event, or activity and the Table Tennis Parties shall comply with such order.

In the event that any ITTF Member Association or, affiliated organisation, undertakes any investigation or proceeding against a Table Tennis Party and the ITTF Integrity Unit reasonably deems that such investigation and/or proceeding is not conducted in a satisfactory manner, the ITTF Integrity Unit may direct for such investigation or proceeding to be transferred to the ITTF Integrity Unit.

question: What specific steps would the Referral process take if the investigation identifies conduct that warrants harsher sanctions?
reasoning: Requires combining 9.24.2 (Referral details) and 9.24.7 (investigation and potential referral withdrawal)
answer_texts: The Referral will set out: (1) The name of the Alleged Person who is the subject of the Referral (the “Respondent”); (2) Full details of the alleged violation, including where, when and how it is alleged to have occurred; (3) The specific provisions of the Applicable Rules alleged to have been violated; (4) Details of any relevant evidence, including copies of any relevant documents; and (5) What sanctions proposed from the list of potential sanctions set out in R9.28. 9: Integrity Regulations ITTF Statutes 2025   Page 238

If upon investigation, the Appropriate Person identifies facts that suggest the sanctions set out in R9.24.10 may not be sufficient, given the conduct of the Alleged Person, the Appropriate Person may raise this with the ITTF Head of Integrity, who will then decide whether to maintain the Referral or else withdraw the Referral and pursue the matter in accordance with the ordinary procedures set out above.

question: How does the ITTF Integrity Unit handle national versus international integrity investigations?
reasoning: Requires combining 9.25.2 (cooperation with ITTF Integrity Unit) and 9.25.3 (directing national investigations to Member Associations)
answer_texts: Where the ITTF Integrity Unit makes a direction pursuant to R 9.25.1, the relevant ITTF Member Association or, affiliated organisation, or World Table Tennis shall take all necessary steps to effect the transfer of investigation and/or proceeding promptly and to assist the ITTF Integrity Unit in coducting the investigation and/or proceeding efficiently, including providing the ITTF Integrity Unit access to or copies of relevant documents, records, articles, and such other information.

Where the ITTF Integrity Unit receives a complaint which is purely national in nature (i.e. has no cross-border element to it), then it may direct the relevant ITTF Member Association or affiliated organisation to conduct the investigation. If the ITTF Integrity Unit does so, the ITTF Member Association or affiliated organisation must provide regular updates to the ITTF Integrity Unit on the progress of the investigation.

question: What are the responsibilities of ITTF Member Associations or affiliated organisations when conducting investigations on behalf of the ITTF Integrity Unit?
reasoning: Requires combining 9.25.3 (directing national investigations) and 9.25.2 (cooperation with ITTF Integrity Unit)
answer_texts: Where the ITTF Integrity Unit makes a direction pursuant to R 9.25.1, the relevant ITTF Member Association or, affiliated organisation, or World Table Tennis shall take all necessary steps to effect the transfer of investigation and/or proceeding promptly and to assist the ITTF Integrity Unit in coducting the investigation and/or proceeding efficiently, including providing the ITTF Integrity Unit access to or copies of relevant documents, records, articles, and such other information.

Where the ITTF Integrity Unit receives a complaint which is purely national in nature (i.e. has no cross-border element to it), then it may direct the relevant ITTF Member Association or affiliated organisation to conduct the investigation. If the ITTF Integrity Unit does so, the ITTF Member Association or affiliated organisation must provide regular updates to the ITTF Integrity Unit on the progress of the investigation.
